articles.title: Monkeypox linked to penis swelling and rectal pain in ongoing outbreak
articles.description: Penis swelling and rectal pain don't normally occur with monkeypox, but a study of around 200 men in London suggests the symptoms may be common in the latest outbreak
articles.content:
By Jason Arunn Murugesu
Monkeypox virus particles
KATERYNA KON/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY
Penile swelling and rectal pain are being reported by some people infected with monkeypox during the latest out… [+3371 chars]

articles.title: Climate change made UK 40°C heatwave at least 10 times more likely
articles.description: The estimate is thought to be on the low side, because climate models are not doing a good job of reproducing how fast temperatures have risen in western Europe
articles.content:
By Adam Vaughan
A wildfire that hit the Shiregreen area of Sheffield, England, on 20 July 2022
Christopher Furlong/Getty Images

articles.title: Fraudsters able to get material for a ‘dirty bomb’, finds US watchdog
articles.description: Investigators in the US found they could acquire enough radioactive material to build a "dirty bomb" by using fake companies and fraudulent licences
articles.content:
By James Dinneen
Radioactive material is used in a “dirty bomb”

articles.title: Ultrasound stickers could continuously image internal organs for days
articles.description: A patch the size of a postage stamp can continuously deliver ultrasound imaging for 48 hours, and it has been used to see changes in the lungs, heart and stomach of people exercising and drinking
articles.content:
By Jeremy Hsu
An ultrasound patch made with a water-based hydrogel

articles.title: ‘Artificial synapse’ could make neural networks work more like brains
articles.description: Networks of nanoscale resistors that work in a similar way to nerve cells in the body could offer advantages over digital machine learning

articles.title: Small woodlouse-like crustacean ‘pollinates’ red seaweed with its legs
articles.description: Small crustaceans carry sperm-like bodies from male to female members of the red seaweed Gracilaria gracilis, hinting that pollination could have evolved in the sea rather than on land
articles.content:
By Carissa Wong

articles.title: 40°C heatwave may have killed 1000 people in England and Wales
articles.description: First estimate of extreme heat's impact suggests more than half of the deaths are expected to have been for people aged 85 and older

articles.title: JWST keeps breaking its own record for the most distant galaxy ever
articles.description: The James Webb Space Telescope has begun peering into the early universe, spotting more and more of the very first galaxies that formed after the big bang
articles.content:

articles.title: Disposable paper battery is activated by a drop of tap water

articles.title: Stroke drug improves memory and repairs injured brain tissue in mice
articles.description: Unlike existing treatments that focus on rehabilitation or reducing the risk of an additional stroke, the experimental drug targets the "stickiness" that can prevent injured brain tissue from functioning as it should
articles.content:
By Carissa Wong
A 3D magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the brain of a 65-year-old after a stroke. The orange coloring represents an area of dead tissue
